moves.2... e6: c5 is the Steinitz counter-gambit.  e6 seems like a solid response.
moves.3. h3: This seems a little weak; black's knight has not entered the fray.
moves.3... c5 4. dxc5 Bxc5 5. e3 Ne7 6. Nf3 Nb: Bishop/Knight trade is kind of interesting when it doesn't lead to doubled pawns.
Whoa!  Did white just toss his knight?  e5 puts pressure on the queen.
moves.15... e5: Two pieces threatened with a single pawn move.
moves.16. Qh4: White's queen chooses to kiss the knight good bye before parting.
moves.16... Nf5: Since the bishop is covering the knight, black can take his own sweet time over slaying the white horse.
moves.17. Qg4: Oops!  NxPe3 forks the queen and rook.
moves.17... Nxe3: Now black has traded up a knight and bishop for a knight and rook AND a pawn.
moves.18. Qxc8: ...or a knight and bishop for a knight, pawn, and queen.
moves.18... Raxc8 19. fxe3 exf4 20. Rxf4 Qc5 2: White is preparing to advance the e pawn?
moves.26. Kh2 Qxb2 27. Rxa6: ??  Ok, maybe that move deserved only one ?, but what does white have against that knight?  Surely the black a pawn couldn't be worth all that.
